340.02
   Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
560.09
   Unsafe buildings - see B. & H. Ch.
1367
   1353.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person shall move or cause to be moved any building within, into, through
or from the Village, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the
Building Official, such permit to be known as a house moving permit. Any person
desiring such permit shall file with the Building Official a written
application therefor.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.02  APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   (a)   Moving Within or Into Village. If an application for the permit
required by Section
1353.01 is for moving a building entirely within the Village limits or is for
the moving of a building into the Village from another location, such
application shall be subject to the approval of Council before a permit is
issued and shall specify the following:
      (1)   The character and size of the building to be moved.
      (2)   The reason for such moving.
      (3)   The purpose and occupancy for which such building is to be used.
      (4)   The locations from which and to which such building is to be moved.
      (5)   A plot plan showing the proposed location of the building upon the
property to which such building is to be moved.
      (6)   The streets on, over or through which it is desired to move such
building, indicating exactly and in detail the route to be followed in moving.
      (7)   Whether or not the building conforms to this Building and Housing
Code, the Planning and Zoning Code and the Fire Prevention Code, and whether or
not it conforms to the architecture of the buildings in the immediate area
within which it is to be located.
   (b)   Moving Out of or Through Village. If the building is being moved from
or through the Village to a location outside the Village limits, the
application shall contain the following:
      (1)   The character and size of the building to be moved.
      (2)   The reason for such moving.
      (3)   The locations from which and to which such building is to be moved.
      (4)   The streets on, over or through which it is desired to move such
building, including exactly and in detail the route to be followed in moving. A
copy of this information shall also be given to the Chief of Police by the
applicant.
         (Ord. 1178. Passed 10-9-61.)
   1353.03  INVESTIGATION BY BUILDING INSPECTOR; REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   Upon the filing of an application, the Building Official shall investigate
the physical condition of the building. He or she shall report the results of
his or her investigation to Council, whose approval of the same is required.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.04  MOVING UNFIT BUILDINGS.
   No permit shall be issued to move any building which, in the opinion of the
Building Official, is so constructed or is in such condition as to be
dangerous, is infected with pests or is unsanitary; or if it is a dwelling unit
for human habitation, in a dilapidated condition, defective or in such a
condition of deterioration or disrepair that its relocation at the proposed
site would cause appreciable harm to, or be materially detrimental to, other
property or improvements in the Village; or if the building is of a type
prohibited at the proposed location by any statute of the State or ordinance of
the Village; or if the use of the building at the new location is in violation
of the statutes of the State or the ordinances of the Village; or if the moving
of the building would cause unreasonable damage to the trees, plants, shrubs or
utility poles on or along the public streets. However, if the condition of the
building, in the opinion of the Building Official, is capable of practicable
and effective repair, the permit may be issued upon the terms and conditions
hereinafter set forth.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.05 SCOPE OF PERMITS.
   Issuance of a permit to an applicant shall not be construed as approval by
the Village of any violation of a State statute or Village ordinance.
(Ord. 1178. Passed 10-9-61.)
   1353.06 PERMIT CONDITIONS.
   A house moving permit shall be granted only after the applicant accepts and
complies with the following terms and conditions:
   (a)   The applicant shall not allow the building being moved to remain upon
or in any manner to obstruct the public streets, other than between the hours
of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, or Eastern Daylight Saving
Time, whichever is in effect.
   (b)   The applicant must deposit with the Village Clerk, prior to receiving
the permit, a sum which is double the amount estimated by the Building Official
to be necessary to reimburse the Village for the cost of trimming, moving,
removing or replanting trees or shrubs and of moving, removing or displacing
any poles or other structures supporting any wires, cables or other equipment
upon such poles or structures belonging to the Village. The cost thereof shall
be estimated by the Building Official, and his or her determination shall be
final.
   (c)   The applicant must have procured, in writing, the permission of the
owners of any trees, shrubs, fences, poles, wires, cables or any other physical
structures which must be moved, removed or displaced in order to allow passage
of the building, to move, remove or displace the same. The permit to move such
building will not be issued until such time as such written permissions are
filed with the Clerk.
   (d)   The applicant must deposit with the Clerk a sufficient sum to be used
to pay the overtime wages of any policemen which the Chief of Police determines
are necessary to employ in order to direct traffic and warn pedestrians and
motorists of the obstruction of a building in the process of being moved over
and upon public streets.
   (e)   The applicant shall file with the Clerk a liability insurance policy
issued by a solvent insurance company authorized to do business in the State,
which policy shall conform in all respects to the requirements of this chapter.
However, in lieu of filing such insurance policy, a certificate must show that
a policy meeting the requirements of this section has been issued, and shall
set forth its expiration date.
   (f)   The applicant shall provide copies of notification letters to all
utility companies affected by the move. Any response or special condition
requirements by the utility company shall also be submitted to the Building
Official.
      (Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.07  LIABILITY INSURANCE; AMOUNTS.
   The liability policy required under this chapter shall insure the person,
partnership, corporation or other organization moving a building against loss
from liability imposed by law for injury or death to any person, and for injury
to the property of any person, including the Village, that occurs while the
mover of a building is so engaged upon the streets of the Village. Such policy
shall insure the mover in the amounts set forth hereinafter, exclusive of
interest and costs:
   (a)   For injury to, or for the death of, any one person, five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000);
   (b)   For injuries to, or for the deaths of, or for any combination of
injuries and deaths of, more than one person arising from any single accident,
one million dollars ($1,000,000);
   (c)   For damage to the property of any person, including the Village,
arising from any single incident, two hundred fifty thousand dollars
($250,000).
      (Ord. 2021. Passed 8-10-81.)
   1353.08 PERMIT ISSUANCE; FEE.
   The permit shall be issued by the Building Official after the above
conditions have been met and agreed to and after the applicant has paid the
permit fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000). The Clerk shall not issue such
permit until he or she has received notification from the Building Official and
the Chief of Police that all requirements of their offices have been met.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.09 NOTICE OF MOVING.
   Notice must be given by the person to whom the permit is issued, or by his
or her representative, to both the Building Official and the Chief of Police,
not less than thirty-six hours nor more than forty-eight hours before the
actual work of moving a building or structure is to commence. (Ord. 2014-03.
Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.10  NONCOMPLIANCE; NOTICE TO PERFORM; PERFORMANCE BY VILLAGE.
   (a)   Whenever a default has occurred in the performance of any term or
condition of any permit, written notice thereof shall be given to the permittee
by the Building Official. Such notice shall state the work to be done, the
estimated cost thereof and the period of time deemed to be reasonably necessary
to complete such work.
   (b)   After receipt of such notice, the permittee must, within the time
therein specified, either cause the work to be done or pay over to the Clerk
the estimated cost of doing such work as set forth in the notice, plus ten
percent thereof. Upon receipt of notice from the Clerk that the permittee has
deposited such money, the Building Official shall cause the required work to be
performed and completed. If the permittee defaults and fails to complete the
moving of the building, the Village shall have the option, in lieu of
completing the work required, to demolish the building and to clear, clean and
restore the site or sites.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.11  APPROVAL OF STREETS; MOVING EQUIPMENT.
   The streets over which any building is to be moved must be approved by the
Building Official and the Chief of Police. All equipment for moving buildings,
except that provided with rubber treads, shall be provided with means to
prevent the picking up of asphalt from the pavement. Such means may include
automatic or manual application of a suitable solvent, but only to the extent
that no excess is left on the pavement. Such means shall be used whenever
necessary, in the opinion of the Building Official, to prevent damage to
pavements. If he or she shall find that such means are not in use when
necessary, or are ineffective, he or she shall immediately order the work
stopped until the necessary precautions are taken to prevent damage.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.12  FOUNDATION REQUIRED.
   No person, either as the mover or the one causing the moving to be done, as
the owner of the real property, or as the owner of a building, shall permit any
building which has been moved to be placed upon any real property within the
Village unless a suitable foundation has already been erected and is ready for
the building to be placed and anchored upon such foundation.
(Ord. 1178. Passed 10-9-61.)
   1353.13  BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS.
   The person having charge of the moving of any building shall maintain at all
times proper flags, lights, barricades and other danger signals, whenever such
building is on any public street. (Ord. 1178. Passed 10-9-61.)
   1353.14  DAMAGE TO PUBLIC PROPERTY; REMEDIES OF VILLAGE.
   In the event that the moving of any building for which a permit shall have
been granted under this chapter causes damage to the public streets or other
public property and improvements, the Building Official, in addition to any
other remedy the Village may have, may cause such damage to be repaired, and
the costs thereof shall be deducted from the deposit required by Section
1353.06(b), or the Building Official may require the person to whom such a
permit has been granted, or his or her authorized representative, upon written
notification from the Building Official, to make all necessary repairs to such
streets, property and improvements. However, should such person to whom such
permit has been granted and to whom such notice has been given, or his or her
authorized representative, fail to make such necessary repairs within the
period of time designated in such written notice, the Building Official may
cause such necessary repairs to be made and the costs thereof deducted from the
deposit required by Section
 1353.06(b), or may proceed to exercise any other remedies which the Village
may have.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.15  COMPLETION OF WORK; REFUND OF DEPOSIT; LIABILITY FOR EXCESS COSTS.
   When the moving of any building for which a permit has been granted is
completed and all damage to public streets or other public property has been
repaired, and the cost of repairing the damage and of performing other work as
provided for in this chapter shall have been paid out of the deposit required
by Section
1353.06(b), such portion of the deposit then remaining unused under the
provisions of this chapter shall be refunded, upon the surrender of the deposit
receipt. Should the cost, however, of repairing the aforesaid damage or
performing other work exceed the total amount of money deposited, the person to
whom such permit was granted shall be liable for the amount of damages or other
costs which are in excess of the amount deposited.
(Ord. 2021. Passed 8-10-81.)
   1353.16 PERMIT REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION; APPEAL.
   (a)   The Building Official or the Chief of Police may at any time, for
sufficient cause, revoke or suspend any permit granted under this chapter. Any
person excepting to any denial, suspension or revocation of a permit applied
for or held by him or her pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or to any
other action taken by any official of the Village concerning such permit, may
appeal in writing to Council by filing with the Clerk a written notice of such
appeal, setting forth the specific grounds thereof.
   (b)   Such notice must be filed within fourteen days after notice of the
action appealed from is received by the appellant, but in no event later than
thirty days after date of such action. The Clerk shall set the matter for
hearing before Council at the next Council meeting and cause notice thereof to
be given to the appellant not less than five days prior thereto. At such
hearing the appellant must show cause, on the grounds specified in the notice
of appeal, why the action excepted to should not be approved. Council may
continue such hearing from time to time, and its findings on the appeal shall
be final and conclusive in the matter, subject to the provisions of Ohio R.C.
Chapter 2506.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1353.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1355
Off-Street Parking Facilities
1355.01   Accessory off-street parking facilities defined.
1355.02   Facilities required for institutional and commercial uses.
1355.03   Facilities required for new construction and uses or for altered
existing structures and uses.
1355.04   Maintenance of facilities.
1355.05   Schedule of required facilities; fractional units.
1355.06   Surface improvement of facilities.
1355.07   Approval by Architectural Board of Review required.
1355.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal off-street parking facilities - see Ohio R.C. 717.05, 727.171
   Impounding of vehicles; redemption - see TRAF.
304.05,
352.02
   Parking generally - see TRAF. Ch.
352
   Loading zones - see TRAF.
 352.09
   Parking for providers of communication towers in residential districts - see
B. & H.
1373.11
   1355.01 ACCESSORY OFF-STREET PARKING FACILITY DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "accessory off-street parking facility" means an
open or enclosed area, accessible from a street, for the parking of motor
vehicles of owners, occupants, employees, customers or tenants of the main
building use. Each facility shall be at least 180 square feet in area, nine by
twenty feet, exclusive of all drives and turning space and determined from an
accurate plan of the area.
(Ord. 1081. Passed 6-30-59.)
   1355.02 FACILITIES REQUIRED FOR INSTITUTIONAL AND COMMERCIAL USES.
      Before proceeding with the construction or alteration of any building or
structure designed or intended for institutional, retail business or office
use, the owner of such building or structure shall provide for off-street
parking facilities accessory to such use as hereinafter required. No permit for
such construction or alteration shall be issued unless and until such accessory
off-street parking facilities shall be so provided for.
(Ord. 1081. Passed 6-30-59.)
   1355.03 FACILITIES REQUIRED FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION AND USES OR FOR ALTERED
EXISTING STRUCTURES AND USES.
   Accessory off-street parking facilities, including access driveways, shall
be determined in conformity with this chapter and shall be provided for as a
condition precedent to the occupancy and use of such building or structure, as
follows:
   (a)   Whenever a building or structure is constructed or a new use
established, facilities shall be provided as to the new structure and to the
extent of the new use provided on the same lot or on an adjoining lot under the
same ownership; or
   (b)   Whenever the use of an existing building or structure is changed to a
use requiring more parking facilities, or whenever an existing building is
altered and there is an increase in the seating capacity or floor areas of the
building or structure, facilities shall be provided for the additional building
or alteration on the same lot or on an adjoining lot under the same ownership.
(Ord. 1081. Passed 6-30-59.)
   1355.04  MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES.
   All accessory off-street parking facilities shall continue unobstructed in
operation, shall not be used for automobile service or repair and shall not be
reduced below the required size as long as the main use remains, unless an
equivalent number of facilities is provided for such use in another approved
location.
(Ord. 1081. Passed 6-30-59.)
   1355.05  SCHEDULE OF REQUIRED FACILITIES; FRACTIONAL UNITS.
   (a)   The number of off-street parking facilities to be provided in
accordance with this chapter shall be determined as follows:
 
Building or Use                  Required Min. Parking
                                 Facilities (Spaces)
Medical and dental offices       1 space per 50 sq. ft. of floor area.
Other offices                    1space per 400 sq. ft. of floor area
Retail stores, banks and service 1 space per 250 sq. ft. area of ground
establishments                   floor area.
                                 1 space per 100 sq. ft. of floor area, or 1
Eating places, bars, taverns     space per each 2 seats, whichever requires
                                 the greater number of spaces.
Public buildings, municipal and  1 space for each full-time employee, plus 1
educational                      space for each 6 seats in assembly rooms.
   (b)   These minimum requirements are also the maximum requirements, unless
the applicant shows extraordinary circumstances that necessitate additional
parking beyond these maximums.
   (c)   Location of Required Parking Spaces.
Off-Street Parking. Required off-street parking spaces for any use shall be
located on the same parcel as the use they are intended to serve, except where
these regulations allow shared parking between uses on different lots pursuant
to subsection (d) below.
   (d)   Joint or Collective Parking Facilities. Shared parking facilities are
strongly encouraged and are permitted if multiple uses cooperatively establish
and operate the facilities and if these uses generate parking demands primarily
during hours when the remaining uses are not in operations. (For example, if
one use operates during evenings or week days only.) The applicant shall have
the burden of proof for a reduction in the total number of required off-street
parking spaces, and documentation shall be submitted substantiating their
reasons for the requested parking reduction. Shared parking may be approved if:
      (1)   A sufficient number of spaces are provided to meet the highest
demand of the participating uses;
      (2)   Evidence to the satisfaction of the Planning Commission has been
submitted by the parties operating the shared parking facility, describing the
nature of the uses, the times when the uses operate so as to demonstrate the
lack of potential conflict between them and compliance with handicapped parking
requirements; and
      (3)   Additional documents, covenants, deed restrictions or other
agreements as may be deemed necessary by the Planning Commission are executed
to assure that the required parking spaces provided are maintained and uses
with similar hours and parking requirements as those uses sharing the parking
facilities remain for the life of the development.
         (Ord. 2005-20. Passed 7-12-05.)
 
   1355.06  SURFACE IMPROVEMENT OF FACILITIES.
   Accessory off-street parking facilities and access driveways shall have a
concrete, asphalt or other hard surface and shall provide adequate drainage so
that all water is drained within the lot on which the parking area or driveway
is located in such manner that water shall not drain across other public or
private property. Appropriate bumper guards or concrete or stone curbs shall be
provided in order to define parking space or limits of paved areas and to
prevent vehicles from projecting into the required yards. (Ord. 1081. Passed 6-
30-59.)
   1355.07 APPROVAL BY ARCHITECTURAL BOARD OF REVIEW REQUIRED.
   Detailed drawings of accessory off-street parking facilities, including
access driveways, shall be submitted for approval by the Architectural Board of
Review before an application for a building permit is approved. Such drawings
shall set forth and show the number of parking spaces and locations, dimensions
and descriptions of all features enumerated and required by this chapter.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1355.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1361
Storage and Screening
1361.01   Storage and screening of vehicles in residential areas.
1361.02   Storage and screening of antennas.
1361.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal regulation of fences - see Ohio R.C. 715.27
   Hedge fences - see Ohio R.C. 971.03, 971.27 et seq.
   Impounding of motor vehicles - see TRAF.
304.05,
352.02
   Parking of junk vehicles - see TRAF.
352.05
   Storage of junk vehicles - see GEN. OFF.
560.07
   Fences in lots and yards - see P. & Z.
1163.11;
1163.20
   Landscape buffers for communication antennas and towers - see B. & H.
1373.09(b)
   Fences for communication antennas and towers - see B. & H.
 1373.09(c)
   1361.01 STORAGE AND SCREENING OF VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.
   (a)   No vehicle shall be stored upon any premises in a residential use
district within the Village except passenger automobiles, except that private
mobile recreational facilities, including motor vehicles, boats and
recreational trailers used solely for recreational purposes by the residents of
the premises, and small panel or pick-up trucks, may be stored on the premises
in a garage building or outside if adequately screened, but the same shall not
be used for sleeping or eating purposes within the Village.
   (b)   No such recreational vehicle, trailer or truck shall be stored outside
of a garage until the adequacy of screening has been determined by the
Architectural Board of Review based upon a screening plan submitted to the
Board and upon the following factors:
      (1)   The location of the screened area relative to adjacent residences;
      (2)   The size and condition of the vehicle;
      (3)   The view of the screened area from the street; and
      (4)   The size, quantity and quality of screening. Adequate screening may
consist of building walls, fencing as permitted by this Building and Housing
Code, or approved by the Board, or planting.
    (c)   At least five days before the Board makes any determination as to the
adequacy of screening, notices shall be sent to the owners of contiguous
properties. After such determination has been made, notice thereof shall be
promptly given to the applicant and to the owners of contiguous properties.
Such determination shall not become effective for ten days thereafter and, if
an appeal is filed with Council by an owner of contiguous property, such
determination shall not become effective until such appeal has been decided by
Council or for sixty days, whichever is earlier. (Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1361.02 STORAGE AND SCREENING OF ANTENNAS.
   (a)   No ground-based antenna shall be installed or maintained within the
Village until the adequacy of its screening has been determined by the
Architectural Board of Review, based upon a screening plan submitted to the
Board and upon the following factors:
      (1)   The location of the screened area relative to adjacent residences
and other structures, provided that no such antenna shall be erected within
forty feet of any lot line;
      (2)   The size and shape of the antenna and its mounting, provided that
the maximum diameter of such antenna shall not exceed twelve feet;
      (3)   The view of the screened area from the street and from adjoining
residences; and
      (4)   The size, quantity and quality of screening. Adequate screening may
consist of walls, fencing or plantings, which shall be continuously maintained,
as approved by the Board.
   (b)   No roof-mounted antenna which is five feet or greater in height or
diameter shall be erected on the rooftop of any building unless such
installation has been approved by the Board based upon the following factors:
      (1)   The size and shape of the antenna and its mounting, provided that
the maximum diameter of such antenna shall not exceed twelve feet; and
      (2)   The view of the antenna from the street and from adjoining
residences.
   (c)   No antenna shall be linked to receivers which are not located on the
same lot.
   (d)   At least five days before the Board is to make a determination as to
either the adequacy of the screening plans under subsection (a) hereof or the
installation of a roof-mounted antenna under subsection (b) hereof, notices
shall be sent to the owners of contiguous properties, including those across
any road or access easement. After such determination has been made, notice
thereof shall be given promptly to the applicant and to the owners of such
contiguous properties. Such determination shall not become effective for ten
days thereafter and, if an appeal is filed with the Council by an owner of any
such contiguous property, such determination shall not become effective until
such appeal has been decided by Council or for sixty days, whichever is
earlier. (Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1361.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1363
Topsoil Removal
1363.01   Permit required.
1363.02   Permit application.
1363.03   Hearing by Planning and Zoning Commission; permit issuance or denial;
appeals; bond.
1363.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Urban sediment pollution - see Ohio R.C. 1501.01, 1501.20
   Soil and water conservation districts - see Ohio R.C. 1515.01 et seq.
   Planning and Zoning Commission - see P. & Z. Ch.
1111
   Erosion and sedimentation control - see P. & Z. Ch.
1171
   Building permits and plans - see B. & H. Ch.
1315
   1363.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall strip and remove or cause or permit the stripping and
removal of any loam or topsoil from any land located within the Village, unless
he or she is the holder of or in conformity with a permit to do so issued
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 890. Passed 7-13-53.)
   1363.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring a permit to remove loam or topsoil shall file with the
Building Official a written application therefor. The application shall contain
the following information:
   (a)   The full name and address of the applicant and, if the applicant is a
partnership, the name and address of each of the partners, and, if the
applicant is a corporation, the names of its principal officers;
   (b)   A description of the land from which the topsoil is to be stripped and
removed, specifying the quantity of land involved;
   (c)   The name and address of the owner of the land described, if the
applicant is not such owner, together with the owner's written consent to the
work proposed, which consent must be attached to the application;
   (d)   The method of stripping and removal to be employed;
   (e)   The time within which the work will be commenced and completed. The
type of reseeding and replanting proposed for the land;
   (f)   The depth of topsoil now on the property, the amount proposed to be
removed and the amount to remain;
   (g)   The method of drainage to be used during the operation and after its
completion, and the topography of the land after removal;
   (h)   The ultimate proposed use of the land after removal of the topsoil;
   (i)   A statement that the applicant will bear the expense of a Village
inspector during the operation under the permit;
   (j)   A statement that the applicant is capable of and will furnish a
performance bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each acre
or fraction thereof included in the permit; and
   (k)   Such other information as the Building Inspector shall deem necessary.
      (Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1363.03 HEARING BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION; PERMIT ISSUANCE OR
DENIAL; APPEALS; BOND.
   (a)   The Building Official shall investigate the statements contained in
the application and shall report the application and his or her findings to the
Planning and Zoning Commission. The Commission shall set a date for a hearing
upon the application and shall notify the applicant of such date. If, after a
hearing, the Commission determines that the granting of the application will
not adversely affect the public welfare, health, safety and convenience, it
shall grant the application with such conditions as it may specify relating to
the method of stripping and removal, the term of the permit, the amount of
topsoil or loam to be left on the land, which shall not be less than three
inches, the reseeding or replanting, the drainage or topography and such other
conditions as the Commission may deem necessary for the protection of the
public interest, health, safety and welfare. Any conditions imposed by the
Commission shall be made a part of the permit and constitute limitations
thereon.
   (b)   In the event the Commission denies an application, the applicant may
appeal its decision to Council within thirty days, and Council may, by majority
vote, act on the application, subject to the limitations set forth in this
chapter.
   (c)   Upon granting the application, the Building Official shall be
instructed to issue the permit containing the conditions imposed upon it, if
any, by the granting body, and the permit shall be issued to the applicant upon
the posting of a bond running to the Village and conditioned upon the
performance of the permit in accordance with its terms. Such bond shall be
signed by the applicant and a surety company or two good and sufficient
sureties satisfactory to the Mayor. The bond shall be in the amount of one
thousand dollars ($1,000) for each acre or fraction thereof of property under
the permit. The bond shall be filed with the Clerk.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1363.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1367
Unsafe Structures
1367.01   Definitions.
1367.02   Maintenance requirements; declaration of unsafe buildings or
structures; repairs or demolition.
1367.03   Foundations.
1367.04   Exterior walls and roofs.
1367.05   Insects, vermin and rodents.
1367.06   Accessory structures.
1367.07   Exterior property areas.
1367.08   Inspections; notice of violations.
1367.09   Hearings re violations before Architectural Board of Review.
1367.10   Orders to vacate; posting of signs.
1367.11   Appeals to Council.
1367.12   Repairs.
1367.13   Noncompliance with orders; demolition by Village.
1367.14   Emergencies.
1367.15   Equitable remedies of Village.
1367.16   Recovery of costs.
1367.17   Right of entry.
1367.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Removal of unsafe buildings - see Ohio R.C. 715.26(B), 715.261
   Powers of municipalities to provide for inspections - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
   Inspections of buildings - see Ohio R.C. 737.34 et seq.
   Nuisances - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3767
   Duties of Architectural Board of Review re unsafe buildings - see B. & H.
1313.03
   Moving of unsafe structures - see B. & H.
1353.04
   1367.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Dwelling" means a building used or designed, or intended to be used,
all or in part, for residential purposes.
   (b)   "Exterior property areas" means the yard areas connected with, by
reason of ownership or right of control, or used together with, the dwelling or
structure on the premises.
   (c)   "Structure" means a building or device constructed or used for
nonresidential purposes.
      (Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   (d)   “Noxious weeds” include Russian, Canadian, or common thistle, wild
lettuce, wild mustard, wild parsley, ragweed, milkweed, ironweed, etc. This
term shall not include cultivated flowers, plants or gardens.
      (Ord. 2016-22. Passed 10-10-16.)
 
   1367.02  MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS; DECLARATION OF UNSAFE BUILDINGS OR
STRUCTURES; REPAIRS OR DEMOLITION.
   (a)   All dwellings or structures and all parts thereof, both exterior and
interior, shall be maintained in good repair and shall be capable of performing
the function for which such dwelling or structure, or part of any feature
thereof, was designed or intended to be used.
 
   (b)   All equipment and facilities appurtenant to a dwelling or structure
shall be maintained in good and safe working order.
   (c)   All dwellings or structures which are structurally unsafe, unsanitary
or not provided with adequate safe egress, which constitute a fire hazard or
are otherwise dangerous to human life, or which, in relation to existing use,
constitute a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance,
dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment, are, for the purposes of this
chapter, declared to be unsafe dwellings or structures. All such unsafe
dwellings or structures shall be repaired and rehabilitated or shall be
demolished and removed in accordance with the procedures specified herein.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   (d)   All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from
weeds, plant growth or grass in excess of six (6) inches in height. All noxious
weeds are prohibited. Upon the failure of the owner or person having charge of
the property to cut the grass and other plant growth and to destroy noxious
weeds after service of a notice of violation upon the owner or person having
charge of the property, the owner, the owner’s agent or authorized
representative, or the person in charge of the property shall be subject to
prosecution in accordance with Section
1311.99 of this code.
      (1)   Upon failure to comply with the notice of violation, any duly
authorized employee of the Village or contractor hired by the Village is
authorized to enter onto the property that is the subject of the notice of
violation to cut and/or destroy the grass, weeds, other plant growth, and
noxious weeds thereon, and the costs of the cutting and/or destruction shall be
paid by the owner, the owner’s agent or the person having charge of the
property.
      (2)   The Building Official shall cause an invoice for services rendered
pursuant to subpart (1) of this section to be served on the owner, the owner’s
agent or the person in charge of the property via regular, first-class mail and
upon non-payment of the invoice, the Building Official shall report the
nonpayment of and invoice to the Village Council at an appropriate time.
      (3)   Upon the receipt of the report provided for in subpart (2) of this
section, Council may make written return to the Fiscal Officer of Cuyahoga
County of the Village’s action under the preceding subparts hereof with a
statement of the charges for its services and a proper description of the
premises for the purpose of making the same a lien upon the property and to be
collected as other taxes and returned to the Village with the General Fund.
         (Ord. 2016-22. Passed 10-10-16.)
   1367.03 FOUNDATIONS.
   (a)   All foundations of every dwelling or structure shall be maintained
structurally sound and in good repair.
 
   (b)   All foundations of every dwelling or structure shall be maintained in
such condition as to prevent the accumulation of moisture within the space
enclosed within such foundations.
 
   (c)   All openings into the foundations of every dwelling or structure shall
be protected against the entrance of rodents.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.04 EXTERIOR WALLS AND ROOFS.
   (a)   All exterior walls of every dwelling or structure shall be maintained
weathertight and shall be maintained so as to resist decay or deterioration
from any cause. In order to insure maintenance of weathertight exterior walls
resistant to decay or deterioration, all such walls shall be painted
periodically or otherwise protected.
 
   (b)   All roofs of every dwelling or structure shall be maintained
weathertight. (Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.05 INSECTS, VERMIN AND RODENTS.
   All dwellings or structures and the premises thereof shall be maintained
free from sources of breeding, harborage and infestation by insects, vermin or
rodents.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.06 ACCESSORY STRUCTURES.
   All secondary or appurtenant structures on premises, such as sheds, barns,
garages, fences, etc., shall either be maintained in good repair and free from
health, accident and fire hazards or shall be removed from the premises.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.07  EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS.
   Exterior property areas of all premises shall be kept free of any object,
material or condition which may create a health, accident or fire hazard or
adversely affect the value of surrounding properties, including, but not
limited to, such objects and conditions as the outside storage of seldom-moved
or immovable vehicles in conspicuous positions where such storage is not part
of a business conducted on the premises, and collections of junk, rubbish or
debris outside dwellings or structures in residential or retail zones.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.08  INSPECTIONS; NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   The Building Official shall examine or cause to be examined every
dwelling or structure or portion thereof reported as unsafe or damaged, and if
such structure is found to be in violation of this chapter, the Building
Official shall give to the owner of such dwelling or structure written notice
stating the defects discovered.
   (b)   The notice shall advise the owner that a hearing concerning the
enumerated defects has been scheduled before the Architectural Board of Review
at a specified time and place, and that the owner may appear in person or by
agent or attorney, to show cause why such defects should not be repaired or the
dwelling or structure demolished.
   (c)   The notice shall be given by registered mail, return receipt
requested. If the person to whom a notice is addressed cannot be found within
the County after reasonable search, then the notice shall be sent by registered
mail to the tax mailing address of such person as shown by the records of the
County Auditor, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous
place on the dwelling or structure to which it relates.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.09 HEARINGS RE VIOLATIONS BEFORE ARCHITECTURAL BOARD OF REVIEW.
   (a)   The Architectural Board of Review shall schedule a hearing on all
violations of this chapter reported by the Building Official, the time and
place of which shall be included in the notice to the owner as provided in
Section
1367.08.
   (b)   In passing on such violations the Board shall require the submission
of evidence to substantiate all claims and may require such additional data as,
in the opinion of the Board, are needed for adequate consideration of
violations. Any member of the Board or any person authorized by the Board may,
at any reasonable time, enter, inspect and examine any dwelling or structure
for the purpose of carrying out the duties of the Board.
   (c)   The Board shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable
or unnecessary delay. Every decision of the Board shall be in writing, shall be
dated, shall indicate the vote upon a decision and shall be promptly filed in
the office of the Building Official. A certified copy of the decision shall be
sent by registered mail to the owner, return receipt requested, and a copy
shall be publicly posted in the office of the Building Official for two weeks
after mailing.
   (d)   If the Board determines that the owner is in violation of this
chapter, its decision shall specify the particular sections of this chapter
which have been violated and shall give the owner a reasonable time to complete
specified repairs or improvements or to demolish and remove the dwelling or
structure or a portion thereof. The decision shall also advise the owner that
he or she is entitled to a hearing before Council if he or she requests it by
filing a notice of appeal with the Board within thirty days of the date of the
Board's decision.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.10 ORDERS TO VACATE; POSTING OF SIGNS.
   If the Architectural Board of Review determines that the condition of any
dwelling or structure is such as to render its continued occupancy hazardous
because of structural, sanitary or fire hazards, it may order the premises
wholly or partially vacated. The Building Official shall carry out such an
order by posting at each entrance of such dwelling or structure a notice to
read: "DO NOT ENTER. UNSAFE TO OCCUPY". Architectural Board of Review. Such
notice shall remain posted until the required repairs, demolition or removal is
completed. Such notice shall not be removed without written permission of a
majority of the Board, and no person shall enter the dwelling or structure
except for the purpose of making the required repairs, demolishing it or as
authorized under Section
1367.11.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.11 APPEALS TO COUNCIL.
   (a)   Upon the filing of a notice of appeal with the Architectural Board of
Review, the Board shall transmit to Council all of the original papers
considered in issuing its decision.
   (b)   Council shall schedule a hearing within a reasonable time after an
appeal has been filed and shall notify the owner of the time and place of the
hearing by registered mail, return receipt requested. Council shall also cause
notice of the filing of the appeal to be sent by registered mail, return
receipt requested, to all abutting and adjoining property owners and others
considered by the Council to be affected by the proposed appeal. A reasonable
time, not less than ten days, shall be allowed for a reply from the property
owners before action is taken on the appeal by Council. The notice provided for
in this section shall be sent by registered mail to the address of the property
owners appearing on the County Auditor's current tax list or the Treasurer's
current mailing list. The failure of delivery of such notice shall not
invalidate the action of Council. However, if notice is inadvertently not given
to a property owner to whom notice should have been given, said property owner
can protest the Council's decision and the Council can reconsider and revoke
its prior action, provided that the applicant is not prejudiced by the
Council's action.
   (c)   The owner may appear at the hearing in person, by agent or by
attorney.
   (d)   In passing on such appeals Council shall require the submission of
evidence to substantiate all claims and may require such additional data as, in
the opinion of Council, are needed for adequate consideration of the appeal.
Any member of Council or any person authorized by Council may, at any
reasonable time, enter, inspect and examine any dwelling or structure for the
purpose of carrying out the duties of Council.
   (e)   Council shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or
unnecessary delay. Every decision of Council shall be in writing, shall be
dated, shall indicate the vote upon a decision and shall be promptly filed with
the Clerk. A certified copy of the decision shall be sent by registered mail to
the owner, return receipt requested, and a copy shall be publicly posted in the
office of the Clerk for ten days after mailing.
   (f)   If Council determines that the owner is in violation of this chapter,
its decision shall specify the particular sections of this chapter which have
been violated and shall give the owner a reasonable time to complete specified
repairs or improvements or to demolish and remove the dwelling or structure or
a portion thereof.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.12 REPAIRS.
   (a)   All repairs to existing dwellings or structures shall be subject to
inspection by the Building Official.
   (b)   All repairs requiring the issuance of a building permit shall be
carried out in accordance with the provisions of this Building and Housing
Code.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.13  NONCOMPLIANCE WITH ORDERS; DEMOLITION BY VILLAGE.
   If the owner of a dwelling or structure fails to comply with a final order
to repair or demolish a dwelling or structure, then the Building Official,
after notice has first been given as provided in Ohio R.C. 715.26, may cause
the dwelling or structure to be demolished, and the costs shall be assessed
against the premises in accordance with Section
1367.16.  
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.14 EMERGENCIES.
   In cases of emergency which, in the opinion of the Building Official,
involve immediate danger to human life or health, the Building Official shall,
after notice has first been given as required by Ohio R.C. 715.26, promptly
cause the dwelling, structure or portions thereof to be made safe or to be
removed. For this purpose he or she may at once enter such dwelling or
structure or the land on which it stands, or abutting lands or structures, with
such assistance at such cost as he or she may deem necessary. He or she may
order adjacent dwellings or structures and premises to be vacated and protect
the public by ordering the erection of an appropriate fence or such other means
as may be necessary, and for this purpose may close a public or private way.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.15 EQUITABLE REMEDIES OF VILLAGE.
   The imposition of any penalty shall not preclude the Village from
instituting an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of proper
jurisdiction to prevent unlawful construction, reconstruction, alteration,
repair, conversion, maintenance or use; to restrain, correct or abate a
violation; to prevent the occupancy of a dwelling or structure or to prevent an
illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about any dwelling or structure; or
to require compliance with provisions of this chapter or other applicable laws,
ordinances, rules or regulations of the Village or the orders or determinations
of the Building Official, the Architectural Board of Review or Council.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.16  RECOVERY OF COSTS.
   The total costs of removing insecure, unsafe or structurally defective
dwellings or structures, including the cost of service or publication of the
notice, whether such costs are incurred due to the use of employees, materials
and equipment of the Village or by contract for labor, materials and equipment,
or both, together with a proper description of the premises, shall be certified
by the Clerk to the County Auditor, to be placed by him or her upon the tax
duplicate to be collected as other taxes. All other costs incurred under this
chapter shall be paid out of the Village Treasury, and the Village may
institute an appropriate action in the courts to recover such costs from the
owner of the premises.
(Ord. 1340. Passed 2-14-66.)
   1367.17  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The right of the Building Official or a member of Council or the
Architectural Board of Review to inspect or examine a dwelling or other
structure under this chapter is subject to the necessity of obtaining a proper
warrant in those instances where entry is refused, in accordance with the due
process requirements of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States
Constitution.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1367.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1371
Water
1371.01   Supply requirements.
1371.02   Source of supply.
1371.03   Inspections; authority of Building Official re contaminated supply.
1371.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to provide and regulate water system - see Ohio R.C. 715.08, 717.01,
743.01
   Water pollution - see Ohio R.C. 715.08, 743.25
   Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23
   Management and control of waterworks - see Ohio R.C. 735.28 et seq., 743.26
et seq.
   Tampering with water hydrants, pipes or meters, unauthorized connections -
see Ohio R.C. 4933.22
   Prosecutions for theft of utilities - see GEN. OFF.
 542.26
   Water generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
931
   Permits and charges for connection to the public water supply system - see
S.U. & P.S.
931.01 et seq.
   Water in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1139.05
   1371.01  SUPPLY REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   A constant and dependable supply of water, of quality suitable for
drinking purposes, shall be provided or developed for the use of the occupants
of every dwelling or other structure, and the daily quantity of such water
constantly available shall not be less than 100 gallons for every sleeping room
of a dwelling and fifty gallons for every animal to be accommodated in a
stable.
   (b)   The Building Official shall not issue any building permit until he or
she shall have been satisfied that the foregoing requirements have been fully
complied with.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1371.02  SOURCE OF SUPPLY.
   The source of a water supply may be from public or private mains, deep wells
or springs. No water shall be used from any surface well or spring which, in
the judgment of the Building Official, is exposed to contamination, except for
purposes of irrigation. Every deep well shall be cased or enclosed in such a
way as to exclude surface water or water from strata near the surface exposed
to contamination.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1371.03  INSPECTIONS; AUTHORITY OF BUILDING OFFICIAL RE CONTAMINATED SUPPLY.
   The Building Official shall have the power to examine or cause to be
examined the condition of any water supply at any time. Whenever such supply is
found unfit for drinking purposes, he or she may direct and enforce such
remedial measures, or condemn and prohibit the use of such water supply, as he
or she may deem necessary to protect the public health and safety. (Ord. 2014-
03. Passed 4-8-14.)
   1371.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1373
Wireless Communication Antennas and Towers
1373.01   Purpose.
1373.02   Definitions.
1373.03   Permit application review.
1373.04   Submittal requirements.
1373.05   Location; standards
1373.06   Permitted height.
1373.07   Strength.
1373.08   Setback.
1373.09   General design standards; landscape buffers; fences.
1373.10   Visual impact mitigation.
1373.11   Parking.
1373.12   Time limit on project completion.
1373.13   Fees.
1373.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Interrupting or impairing television, radio, telephone, telegraph or other
mass communication service - see Ohio R.C. 2909.04
   Telegraph and telephone companies - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4931
   Powers and restrictions on public utility services - see Ohio R.C. 4931.11
   Threatening or harassing telecommunications - see GEN. OFF.
536.15
   Prosecutions for theft of utilities - see GEN. OFF.
542.26
   Cable television - see B.R. & T. Ch.
711
   Storage and screening of ground and roof-mounted antennas - see B. & H.
1361.02
 
   1373.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to provide a process for permitting the
construction and subsequent maintenance of telecommunications systems,
including towers and antennas. This process is directed at maintaining a
balance between the Village's identified right to preserve its land use
policies for the public health, safety, welfare and aethestics, and the Federal
government's interest in providing for and spurring competition in the
telecommunications arena. All legislation is directed at creating an
environment where residents will have the greatest opportunity to benefit from
the intent of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, to enhance competition while
impacting the Village's land use plan and its property values in the least
intrusive manner possible.
(Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Monopole" means a single, slender and typically cylindrical, vertical
structure to which antennas or antenna support structures are affixed.
   (b)   "Substantial evidence" means more than a mere scintilla of evidence.
It means such relevant evidence as a reasonable mind might accept as adequate
to support a conclusion.
   (c)   "Telecommunications" means technology permitting the passage of
information from the sender to one or more receivers in a usable form by means
of any electromagnetic system.
   (d)   "Wireless communication antenna" means an antenna designed to transmit
or receive communications as authorized by the Federal Communications
Commission (FCC), excluding amateur radio operator's antennas.
   (e)   "Wireless communication tower" means a monopole tower which elevates
the wireless communication antenna and may include accessory transmission and
receiving equipment.
   (f)   "Wireless telecommunication equipment building" means the structure in
which the electronic receiving and relay equipment for a wireless
telecommunication facility is housed.
   (g)   "Wireless telecommunication facility" means a facility consisting of
the equipment and structures involved in receiving telecommunications or radio
signals from a mobile radio communications source and transmitting those
signals to a central switching computer which connects the mobile unit with the
land-based telephone lines.
      (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
 
   1373.03 PERMIT APPLICATION REVIEW.
   (a)   Applicants are encouraged to appear before the Planning Commission for
a pre-review of proposed wireless communication antenna and tower sites, which
pre-review may be conducted by the Planning Commission upon the applicant's
submittal of a site plan with the general location, type of structure and
height being reviewed, and surrounding uses.
 
   (b)   With the formal permit application to the Planning Commission, the
applicant shall file a complete set of plans, specifications and other
submittal requirements required by Section
1373.11, as well as the filing fees required by Section
1373.13.  
 
   (c)   The Planning Commission shall review the application in accordance
with the criteria established in this chapter. The applicant shall appear at
all Planning Commission meetings to answer any questions which may arise from
Commission members and to supply information to the members of the Planning
Commission.
 
   (d)   Prior to taking any action on the application, the Planning Commission
will cause notice of the pending application to be sent by certified mail to
all abutting property owners and property owners within 1,000 feet of the
parcel on which the antenna and/or tower is to be located. The Building
Official may also provide notice by regular first-class mail to any other
property owner in the Village whom he or she feels will be substantially
impacted by the siting of this tower. The failure of the Building Official to
give notice as required in this section shall not affect the validity of the
Planning Commission's action. The foregoing notice requirement may be waived by
the Planning Commission for construction of a new antenna on an existing
structure, which application does not require the construction of a new tower
or associated facilities.
 
   (e)   After conducting its meeting, the Planning Commission may act upon the
application. Any decision to deny a request to place, construct or modify a
wireless communication antenna and/or tower shall be in writing and shall be
supported by substantial evidence contained in a written record of the
proceedings of the Planning Commission.
 
   (f)   Approval by the Planning Commission of the granting of a permit shall
become effective only following review and approval by the Village Council. A
certified copy of a resolution of the Planning Commission granting such permit
shall be filed forthwith by the Secretary of the Planning Commission with the
Clerk of Council. Within the thirty-day period next succeeding such filing,
Council, by a majority vote, must approve, disapprove or approve with
modification the Planning Commission's action in granting the permit. Any
decision to deny a permit to place, construct or modify a wireless
communication antenna and/or tower shall be in writing and supported by
substantial evidence contained in a written record of the proceedings of
Council.
 
   (g)   After approval by Council, any plans for equipment buildings and
accessory structures shall be submitted to the Architectural Board of Review
for review and approval under Chapter
1313 of the Building Code.
 
   (h)   After approval by the Architectural Board of Review, the Building
Official is authorized to issue a permit in accordance with all prior
approvals.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 4-8-14.)
 
   1373.04  SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS.
   The following shall also be submitted to the Gates Mills Planning and Zoning
Commission:
   (a)   An affidavit from the applicant stating that there is a demonstrated
need for the placement of the wireless communication tower in a residential
district and that there is not a technically suitable space available on an
existing tower to accommodate the need;
   (b)   A current certified survey showing existing lots and property
boundaries, streets, rights of way, servitudes, buildings and building
setbacks, surrounding streets, important physical features on the site, the
total square footage of the site, the lot and square number and the name of the
subdivision, if applicable;
   (c)   An affidavit which certifies that the proposed tower is located no
less than 2,500 feet from another wireless communication tower within the
Village;
   (d)   A basic site plan depicting the location and dimensions of all
proposed structures, with setback dimensions, entrances and exits and the
parking layout, including parking spaces;
   (e)   A landscape plan of the site delineating the location of existing
trees to be preserved, the location and dimension of proposed planning areas,
including the size, type and number of trees to be planted, curbs, fences,
buffers and screening elevations of fences and materials used;
   (f)   The location of every tower, building or structure that could support
the proposed antenna so as to allow it to serve its intended function. The
applicant must demonstrate that a technically suitable location is not
reasonably available on an existing tower, building or structure within the
search area.
   (g)   The elevation of existing and proposed structures, showing the width,
depth and height of the structures, the use, types of material and color
schemes of the structures and statistical data on the tower and its related
accessory structure;
   (h)   The zoning classification of the site and the zoning classification of
all property within 500 feet of the proposed site;
   (i)   A utility inventory showing the location of all utilities impacting
the site;
   (j)   An affidavit that the proposed tower meets all the requirements of the
various State and Federal regulatory agencies involved and complies with
standards set by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC);
   (k)   A report from a licensed professional engineer which describes the
tower height and design, including a cross-section of the structure;
demonstrates the tower's compliance with applicable structural standards; and
describes the tower's capacity, including the number and type of search areas
that can be accommodated;
   (l)   An environmental statement fully describing the effects that the
proposed tower will have on the environment and surrounding area, including the
radiological impact on human health and the impact on adjacent residential
structures and streetscapes;
   (m)   A list of all property owners and addressees within 1,000 feet of the
proposed wireless communication facility;
   (n)   A list of competitors, together with their addresses, so that the
Village may notify the competitors of the application in an effort to encourage
co-location; and
   (o)   Photographs showing structures on and uses of adjacent parcels.
      (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.05 LOCATION; STANDARDS.
   Only monopole wireless communication towers and their associated supporting
buildings shall be allowed in the Village. All monopole wireless communication
towers shall meet the following criteria:
   (a)   No new wireless communication facility may be erected if there is a
technically suitable space for a wireless communication facility available on
an existing wireless communication tower within the applicant's search area in
which the new wireless communication antenna is to be located. With the permit
application, the applicant shall list the location of every tower, building or
structure that could support the proposed antenna so as to allow it to serve
its intended function. The applicant must demonstrate that a technically
suitable location is not reasonably available on an existing tower, building or
structure. If another communication tower is technically suitable, the
applicant must show that it has requested to co-locate on the existing tower
and the co-location request was rejected by the owner of the tower. In all
circumstances, owners of existing towers shall promptly respond to requests for
co-location, but in no event shall they respond in more than thirty days from
the date of receipt of written request for co-location. If another
communication tower is technically suitable, the applicant must further show
that it has offered to allow the owner of that other tower to co-locate an
antenna on another tower within the Village owned by the applicant on
reciprocal terms and the offer was not accepted. In all cases, the Village
shall use its best efforts to encourage co-location.
   (b)   As a condition of issuing a permit to construct and operate a tower in
the Village, the owner/operator of the tower is required to allow co-location
until said tower has reached full antenna capacity, but in no event fewer than
two additional antennas for two additional providers. Agreement to this
provision must be included in the lease by the landowner, if different from the
owner/operator of the tower. Written documentation must be presented to the
Planning Commission and Council evidencing that the landowner of the property
on which the tower is to be located has agreed to the terms of this section as
well as the requirements, regulations and standards established in this
chapter. As an additional condition of issuing the permit to construct and
operate the tower in the Village, the owner/operator of the tower is required
to sign a statement that all disputes with future providers concerning co-
location and the terms and conditions of co-location shall be submitted to
commercial arbitration under a system selected by the parties, but if the
parties are unable to agree, then under the auspices of the Commercial
Arbitration Provisions of the American Arbitration Association.
   (c)   The minimum lot size for which a wireless communication tower is to be
located shall be the minimum lot size for a residential district, unless a
variance is granted, and shall be of sufficient size to contain on-site any
debris from tower collapse.
   (d)   No new wireless communication tower will be allowed within a 2,500-
foot radius of an existing cellular tower. The Planning Commission may waive
this requirement with the approval of Council for the purpose of clustering of
towers so long as the towers are visually compatible with the surrounding
neighborhood.
   (e)   A wireless communication antenna may be affixed to existing structures
so long as it complies with Village zoning regulations.
      (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
 
   1373.06  PERMITTED HEIGHT.
   Wireless communication towers may not be erected to a height in excess of
150 feet above ground level. Should the applicant wish to erect a wireless
communication tower in excess of 150 feet, it must seek a variance from the
Planning Commission. In no event, however, shall the Planning Commission have
any authority to grant a variance for a wireless communication tower in excess
of 200 feet.
(Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.07  STRENGTH.
   Towers and antennas shall be designed to withstand sustained winds of at
least eighty miles per hour with one-half inch of icing. An applicant shall
further be required to construct or locate on a base the tower structure and
the structure foundation, which base is designed to be buildable up to, but not
including, the maximum permitted height for that structure. Such structure
shall further be designed to have sufficient structural capacity to allow for
at least three providers to be located on the structure when constructed to the
maximum allowable height. The wireless communication facility shall also be
designed to show that the applicant has enough space on its site for an
equipment building large enough to accommodate at least three providers. If the
equipment building is initially constructed to accommodate only one user, space
shall be reserved on-site for equipment building expansion to accommodate up to
at least two additional providers. The maximum size of above-ground equipment
buildings is 300 square feet for one provider and in no circumstances more than
750 square feet total. (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.08  SETBACK.
   (a)   The wireless communication tower must be set back from all property
lines by a distance of fifty percent of the height of the tower (unless a
larger distance is required by Section
1373.05(c)) or by the rear yard or side yard setback required in the underlying
zoning district, whichever is greater.
 
   (b)   All associated equipment support buildings must meet the minimum
setback standards for accessory structures in the underlying zoning district
and shall not be used for offices, long-term vehicle storage or outdoor
storage.
 
   (c)   In no case shall the wireless communication facility be located in the
required front yard of a lot.
(Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.09 GENERAL DESIGN STANDARDS; LANDSCAPE BUFFERS; FENCES.
   (a)   General Design Standards.
      (1)   The entire facility must be aesthetically and architecturally
compatible with the environment. The use of residentially compatible exterior
materials, such as wood, brick or stucco, is required for associated equipment
buildings, which shall be designed to architecturally match the exterior of
residential structures within the neighborhood. In no case will metal or
concrete block exteriors be allowed for accessory buildings.
      (2)   The tower itself must be of such design and treated with an
architectural material so that it is camouflaged or blends in with surrounding
uses so as to be visually compatible with the neighborhood.
   (b)   Landscape Buffers. Existing on-site vegetation shall be preserved to
the maximum extent practical. All towers shall be landscaped with at least one
row of evergreen shrubs or trees within twenty feet of the tower's base. Such
trees shall be a minimum of six feet high when planted and spaced not more than
ten feet apart. These trees and shrubs shall be planted in any configuration
which will serve to better buffer the site.
   (c)   Fences. Fences constructed of wood, brick or chain link shall be used
to secure the site and provide an opaque barrier. Such fences shall be used in
conjunction with landscaping to provide security or increase the buffer with
the adjacent residential uses. In no case will barbwire or razorwire fencing be
permitted in residential districts. (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
 
   1373.10  VISUAL IMPACT MITIGATION.
   (a)   Color. The wireless communication tower will be constructed of a
material with a neutral color and shall be designed to blend with the
surrounding landscape and uses.
 
   (b)   Light. No exterior lighting of the wireless communication tower is
permitted.    
 
   (c)   Design. The design criteria for wireless communication towers and
their associated support buildings shall follow the provisions outlined above
in Section
1373.09.   
(Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
 
   1373.11 PARKING.
   At least one off-street parking space shall be provided, for each provider,
for towers which are located in residential districts. (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-
97.)
   1373.12  TIME LIMIT ON PROJECT COMPLETION.
   Once a wireless communication tower is approved, the building permit shall
be obtained within six months and the project shall be completed within one
year.    
   All obsolete or unused facilities abandoned for six consecutive months must
be removed within twelve months of cessation of operation at the site.
(Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.13  FEES.
   Before an action shall be taken regarding the application for a wireless
communication facility, the applicant shall deposit with the Planning and
Zoning Commission a fee in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to
supplement the cost of processing the application.
   The applicant shall also place on deposit the amount necessary, but not less
than two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500), for the Village to obtain a
certification from a registered engineer that the proposal is in compliance
with Federal, State and local regulations. (Ord. 2802. Passed 4-8-97.)
   1373.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE; See Section
1311.99 for general Building and Housing Code penalty if no specific penalty is
provided.)
CHAPTER 1375
Residential Building Code
1375.01   2013 Edition adopted; purpose; file and distribution copies.
   1375.01  2013 EDITION ADOPTED; PURPOSE; FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   Pursuant to the provisions of Ohio Revised Code 731.231, there is hereby
adopted by and for the Village, for purpose of regulating and safeguarding the
construction of the residential dwellings, that certain Code known as the
"Residential Code of Ohio for One-, Two-, and Three-Family Dwellings", latest
edition and all revisions. A complete copy of such Code shall be kept in the
